properties.headline: Flood Warning issued February 6 at 10:56PM EST until February 7 at 4:45AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a

* Flood Warning for...
Pickens County in Upstate South Carolina...

* Until 445 AM EST Friday.

* At 1044 PM EST, Pickens County Emergency Management continues
to report numerous roads still closed due to earlier flash
flooding.  Heavy rain has ended across the county with only
light rainfall expected overnight. However, storm-total rainfall
of 5-7 inches county wide is producing runoff that is still
causing rises on larger streams including Twelvemile Creek
near Liberty and Eighteenmile Creek north of Pendleton.
Significant flooding is ongoing on these larger streams and
this flooding is expected to persist through the overnight
hours as it will take some time for these streams to crest and
recede.  Elevated stream levels are expected to persist into
Friday morning. Therefore, though the flash flood threat has
ended for this event, a Flood Warning has been issued to
continue to highlight numerous ongoing flooding impacts.

* Numerous roads will remain closed across the warned area.
DO NOT DRIVE THROUGH FLOODED ROADWAYS. Please obey all barricades.
It is extremely difficult at night to assess the depth of flooding
and roads may be damaged or washed away underneath the flood
waters.  Barricades remain in place until engineers can assess
the stability of the road or bridge and ensure its safety.

* Some locations that may continue to experience flooding include...
Easley, Clemson, Pickens, Central, Liberty, Norris, Six Mile,
Jocassee Gorges, Lake Jocassee and Table Rock State Park.
properties.instruction:
Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

Numerous roads, parking lots and bridges were impacted by
flash flooding. Please pay close attention to road signs indicating
a flood-prone area. Obey all barricades, even if water is not
currently over the road. Barricades are in place for your
protection and indicate areas where flooding can occur rapidly
and without warning.
